page.title: 03 SUGAR LOAF HILL, FOLKESTONE
page.content: Sugar Loaf, a basin-shaped hill 200' high and 400' above sea level, is one of a range of hills behind Folkestone. About 2000 B.C. it was a religious centre for the local tribes, and even today crosses are taken up to commemorate Easter. Passing travellers drew water from Holy Well. In 1905, a sheep dip was in use. Cows, which used to graze the hill, made the paths. In 1940, gun emplacements and tank traps were established to guard against invasion. Canadian soldiers camped here. On July 2nd,1985, Class 6 of Park Farm School visited Sugar Loaf, passing through crop fields. They had a splendid view of Folkestone and could see France. The hill was covered with flowers and grasses and they counted over 300 orchids.This amazing hill is still felt to be a very special place.
